SecurityMeasures: Proper error handling and suppression of error pages
Restricted access to Symfony profiler interface

Steps.Description: Accessing a non-existent page triggers Symfony error pages.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker hypothesizes that the error pages may contain sensitive information or provide access to other parts of the system.
StepDetails.Action: The attacker tries to access various pages to trigger the error pages.
StepDetails.Result: The attacker successfully triggers the Symfony error pages.

Steps.Description: Analyzing the error pages reveals access to the Symfony profiler interface.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker believes that the Symfony profiler interface may provide additional information or functionality.
StepDetails.Action: The attacker navigates to the Symfony profiler interface.
StepDetails.Result: The attacker gains access to the Symfony profiler interface.

Steps.Description: Examining the code in the profiler interface reveals the path to the environment file.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker assumes that the environment file may contain sensitive information, such as database credentials.
StepDetails.Action: The attacker accesses the bootstrap.php file to find the path to the environment file.
StepDetails.Result: The attacker obtains the path to the environment file.

Steps.Description: Accessing the environment file reveals the flag.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker expects that the environment file may contain the flag or other sensitive information.
StepDetails.Action: The attacker accesses the environment file using the provided URL.
StepDetails.Result: The attacker successfully retrieves the flag from the environment file.
